While it is possible that plants do have a level of ability to feel stress 
and suffering, we do not have good scientific evidence that they do. 
Animals, however, have a central nervous system, and so we do know that 
they can objectively feel pain.

Even if plants could suffer and were of equal consciousness as animals are, 
it would be wiser to continue eating plants. Why? Every 10 calories of meat 
requires the sacrifice of 100 calories worth of plants. This is due to the 
trophic pyramid, which explains how energy is distributed throughout an 
ecosystem. See here:

http://www.guidetrainingcourses.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/The-trophic-pyramid-and-flow-of-energy1-660x440.jpg

Eating meat would therefore require the deaths of not only the animal, but 
also the plants that the creature was fed during its life. If we simply ate 
the plants directly, we would be saving plant lives.

+Graham Frost
Oh, Oh, I'm shaking  in my boots! Will your devastating rebuttal include 
more copy-pasted text from AuthorityNutrition.com?

You're not fooling anyone, poseur.

+Graham Frost Well, that was a nice try with the Googling of definitions, 
but you fell right into my trap, in two specific ways.

1) You're still confused about definitions.  By asking me the question, "A 
more important question would be to discuss wether omnivorous 
characteristics are ancestral traits, unique derived traits and/or shared 
derived traits?,"  you are simply repeating my question to you.  But, you 
seem to think it's a different question. 

2)  You didn't recognize that I was asking you a trick question.  
"Omnivorous characters" or "omnivorous traits" are largely meaningless 
terms, since omnivory isn't a trait or specific suite of traits unto 
itself.  That is, it's not a synapomorphy, a plesiomorphy, or an 
autapomorphy.  It's just an informal description for any animal that isn't 
a specialized herbivore or carnivore. It applies to most animals.

If you tried to use omnivory as a phylogenetic tool in an actual evo-bio 
setting, you'd at best get a lot of raised eyebrows.  It's not a recognized 
diagnostic character or suite of characters.  And it certainly isn't used 
in primate cladistics.

The fact that you didn't instantly recognize this as a trick question 
debunks your claim that you've studied evolutionary biology at the uni 
level.  This stuff is covered in freshman- and sophmore-level evo-bio 
classes. So, there's no need to "debunk your conjectures," as I can easily 
debunk your claim that you've studied this material at the uni-level.

Now, for your edification, here are the "tells" from your original post, 
that revealed you have no uni-level background in evo-bio.

-- Your point number 2 contains two of them: "Guess what? Over 70% of the 
foods we eat today did not exist before the industrial revolution. From an 
evolutionary perspective, there is simply no way for our bodies to know 
what to do with these “foods” (which, as we all know, aren’t real food at 
all)"

--- Urm, nope.  We have manipulated these foods to be MORE adapted to our 
bodies.  That's the actual problem.  As animals, we crave fat, salt, and 
sugar, for  perfectly understandable evolutionary reasons.  We have thus 
cultivated a number of food organisms to contain more fat, salt, and/or 
sugar than their ancestors did.  And we did it so well, that these foods 
are making us fatter because they interact with and fool our energy storage 
metabolism so well.

-- "If you're from Europe, is it preferable in your genetic makeup to eat 
bananas that grow in the rainforest????"

-- This one displays your lack of understanding about the concept of 
ancestral (plesiomorphic) traits vs. derived (autapomorphic or 
symapomorphic) traits.  Europeans are not a separate species of H. 
sapiens.  Whatever their regional genetic variations are, they still retain 
all the ancestral traits as other humans.  Thus, yes, Europeans would do 
just fine on fruits from the rainforest, as would all other humans.  We are 
all the same species.  We retain the underlying digestive physiology and 
anatomy of hominoids  going back 22 million years.  Nature didn't 
completely redesign our digestive systems from the ground up when H. 
sapiens emerged.  It just made a few tweaks here and there, and kept 
everything else more or less the same.  That's how ancestral traits work; 
there's usually no need to modify them, so they don't change very much over 
evolutionary times.  This is why, for instance, H. sapiens cannot produce 
vitamin C endogenously and must get it from food.  That's a plesiomorphy we 
inherited from distant hominoid ancestors in the Miocene, who were 
primarily fruit-eaters.

-- Then there's your point number 4: "It was only when we started eating 
animal foods/fish that our brains doubled in size, this is a proven 
scientific fact, allowing for the modern human and all our advances."

-- You are referring here to an idea called the expensive tissue 
hypothesis, first formulated by Aiello & Wheeler in 1995.  While there are 
some problems with the idea, I won't go into them here, because it isn't 
necessary.  You got the hypothesis backwards.

The ETH does NOT say that meat-eating doubled human brain size.  it says 
that an increase in brain size necessitated a dietary shift to more 
calorie-dense foods, in order to compensate for the caloric demands of said 
bigger brains.  In other words, bigger brains led to more meat-eating, not 
the other way around. The evolution of bigger brains came FIRST, followed 
by the increase in meat-eating.

And further, while Aiello & Wheeler postulated that meat was the most 
likely candidate food, they were clear that ANY calorie-dense food source 
would have sufficed.  They specifically cited fruits, tubers, and oil-rich 
nuts and seeds as other potential candidates.

-- Your point number 6 again displays an  ignorance of the concept of 
ancestral vs. derived traits.  The human digestive system, in both its 
anatomy and physiology, retains the template laid down among the hominoids 
22 million  years ago.  It is a modified omni-frugivore digestive system, 
not something totally new.  Calling us "omnivores" is redundant, since all 
primates are to some degree or another; it doesn't distinguish us from 
other primates all that much, and certainly not from our closest relatives 
among the apes.

-- Finally, your entire post displays a fundamental misunderstanding of 
evolution itself.  Human biology has not remained static since the Stone 
Age.  There is no reason, evolutionarily speaking, why it would.  The idea 
that evolution stopped working on us 10,000 years ago is nonsensical, and 
it's a notion that's only really found among pseudo-science hucksters like 
the paleo and low-carb diet gurus, and not among any actual evolutionary 
anthropologists or biologists.

So, it's pretty clear to me that you have not studied evo-bio at the 
university level.  It's best that you just admit you lied about this, 
rather than trying to continue with your Google- and Wikipedia-based shell 
games.  Most  of what you wrote looks like it could have been copy-pasted 
from some paleo-diet website or forum, and for all I know it was.  It 
wouldn't be the first time someone tried that stunt one of these comment 
threads.

(Vegans please read) Ok, so here is my complete thesis into why being 
Vegan is a flawed concept (side note - I have studied nutrition at masters 
level at a top Uk uni, i've also studied dietary history & evolutionary 
biology) I apologise if this gets a bit lengthy. 

Veganism is a deeply flawed concept, both environmentally & dietarily and 
future generation will laugh at this stupid diet, why? 

1) Veganism is a flawed concept. Why? Vegans, amongst other reasons, don't 
eat animal products to avoid the death of animals. But agriculture destroys 
more animals and the environment more than any other method. Growing 
tropical fruits destroys rain forests, shipped from across the planet. Is 
this really sustainable? A single cow can feed a family for a year if 
frozen correctly. Vegan ruins the environment more than ANY OTHER DIET! 

2) Guess what? Over 70% of the foods we eat today did not exist before the 
industrial revolution. From an evolutionary perspective, there is simply no 
way for our bodies to know what to do with these “foods” (which, as we all 
know, aren’t real food at all) If you're from Europe, is it preferable in 
your genetic makeup to eat bananas that grow in the rainforest???? 

3) Broken down by nutrient ratios, what we feed cattle (that isn't grass 
fed/pasteurised) to “fatten them up” is almost identical to the 
government-sanctioned food pyramid for a “healthy” diet! Is it any wonder 
we are in the middle of an obesity epidemic?? 

4) It was only when we started eating animal foods/fish that our brains 
doubled in size, this is a proven scientific fact, allowing for the modern 
human and all our advances. Interesting irony that the very capacity for 
making an argument for a plant-based diet comes from our ancestors’ move 
away from a plant-based diet! Ah, evolution wins EVERY time!!!!!!!!!

5) A recent Australian study was done with a group of aborigine who had 
grown up in a traditional hunter gatherer environments, and then moved into 
urban environments where they adopted modern diets. Alas, lifestyles and 
(unsurprisingly) health concerns such as obesity, type 2 diabetes, and 
heart disease arose. They returned to the outback & their hunter gatherer 
ways for a seven week period. They lost 25 pounds each and all their health 
markers (insulin resistance, blood pressure, cholesterol levels ect) 
normalised. Red meat, poultry, vegetables and seasonal fruits where 
plentiful for these men, I wonder what this study proves???

6) Another interesting point, are humans digestive tracts designed to eat 
meat?? Vegans say no, other people with working brains say YES - it turns 
out that much differs among animals, the markers lay in the composition of 
the digestive tract! Animals have evolved digestive tracts and livers to 
transform diverse food inputs into the uniform set of nutrients that they 
need for optimal health. Herbivores have foregut organs such as rumens or 
hindgut chambers for fermenting carbohydrates, turning them into fats and 
volatile acids that can be used to manufacture fats. Carnivores have livers 
capable of turning protein into glucose and fat.The truth is that humans 
are omnivores, despite what some vegan proponents would have you believe. 
We function best eating BOTH animals and plant together!!!! (Great study - 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10702160) 

7) Guess what? Meat/fish is VERY nutritious!! Did you know, that high 
quality, unprocessed meat is among the most nutritious foods in the world?! 
A 100 gram portion (3.5 ounces) of raw ground beef contains large amounts 
of Vitamin B12, B3 (Niacin), B6, Iron, Zinc, Selenium and plenty of other 
vitamins and minerals (
http://nutritiondata.self.com/facts/beef-products/6193/2) Vitamin B12 is 
particularly important because it can not be obtained in ANY amount from 
plants (arguably some sea veggies contain small traces) Studies show that 
most vegans who don’t supplement with B12, 92% are deficient in this 
critical nutrient (http://www.nutritionj.com/content/9/1/10)
Unprocessed meat is also loaded with healthy fats, but meat from grass-fed 
animals contains up to 5 times as much Omega-3 as meat from grain-fed 
animals!!!! (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18641180) But the nutrient 
composition of meat goes WAY beyond all the macro- and micronutrients that 
we are all familiar with! - CREATINE forms an energy reserve in the muscles 
and brain and is found only in animal foods. Vegetarians are deficient in 
creatine, leading to reduced physical and mental performance (
http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=8207518) 
CARNOSINE functions as a powerful anti-oxidant and provides protection 
against many degenerative processes. Carnosine is only found in animal 
foods (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15872311) DHA and EPA are the 
active forms of Omega-3 in the human body and found primarily in animal 
foods. The body is inefficient at converting ALA (the plant form of 
Omega-3) to the active forms (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11083485)

8) Humans have been eating fish for millions of years, some cultures 
SURVIVE solely on fish and have zero disease. Studies show that regular 
consumption of fish fights

Alzheimer's 
Polyunsaturated fatty acids found in many fish may prevent damage to brain 
cells. Eating fish can also dramatically reduce the risk of high blood 
pressure, which is linked with dementia. A French study of 2000 people 
showed that those who ate seafood at least once a week had a significantly 
lower risk of dementia over a seven-year period than those who didn't.

Cancer
A Swedish study of 6000 men over a 30-year period showed that those who 
didn't eat any fish had between double and treble the risk of developing 
prostate cancer, compared to those who ate moderate or large amounts. 
Shellfish, such as crab and lobster, also contains selenium, thought to 
have cancer-fighting properties.

Depression
It's been reported that fish can help to ease depression. Again, it's down 
to omega-3 fatty acids, which are believed to raise levels of the brain 
chemical serotonin.

Arthritis
Population groups that eat a lot of fish - Inuits in Greenland, for example 
- have low rates of inflammatory conditions such as arthritis. Studies have 
also shown fish oils to be useful in relieving the symptoms of rheumatoid 
arthritis.

Social benefits
According to research carried out in Mauritius, children given lots of fish 
from the age of three are less likely to have criminal records by the time 
they reach 23.

EVEN Skin
According to dermatologist Nicholas Perricone, author of The Perricone 
Prescription, a salmon-packed diet can help smooth out age lines.

9) TESTING - The Vegan diet is rather new in terms of modern human diets. 
We haven't tested the vegan diet long term, I would bet all the money in 
the world in 10 years we will not be eating vegan. We will know the dangers 
& this stupid method of eating will be obsolete.

day like some vegans do is VERY bad for you, thats a lot of

+John Morgan
John, I'm a vegan, too.  And a damned healthy one (I do Tough Mudder races 
and CrossFit workouts).  I didn't mean to make it sound like being healthy 
is hard.  My point is that it's not any harder for a vegan than it is for a 
carnist.  However, it does take some degree of discipline and research, so 
people -- vegan or not -- shouldn't just assume they're eating healthy 
without educating themselves.

That said, I know plenty of fellow vegans who subsist on vegan junk food.  
Perhaps "most" is an over-statement fueled by my anecdotal experience, but 
I don't think average vegans are much different from average people in 
general: most of them will be looking for the most convenient way of 
obtaining calories with the least amount of effort.  That means lots of 
processed food high in fat, sodium, and refined sugar.  Most meat-eaters 
are the same way.

+HumaneHominid I don't know about MOST vegans eating shitty diets. 
(whatever that means, it's far too general and apologetic in my opinion). A

expand your pallet as well.

I have no IDEA where you are drawing your information from about typical

You make it sound so difficult to be healthy. I don't know WHY you're doing 
this, but I have a fantastic time eating plants. It's hilarious. I concede 
this though, it is easier to actually adhere to an eating style if you know 
what you're doing (big surprise ;)). I agree that eating healthy as a vegan 
is no harder than eating as a carnist. I'd actually posit it's easier, just 
from personal experience. I ate animal products for 24 years. I've been 
vegetarian for about two years and vegan for about a year. So far so good. 
A lot of my thoughts have changed so drastically I feel like a different 
human, I understand why it's a sort of ambiguous and unattractive option to 
live on a plant-based diet even given its benefits. It really should be 
under severe consideration the amount of suffering caused to eat animal 
products. Suffering and death is still caused by vegan diets unless the 
utmost care is taken to harvest harmlessly, but it is objectively less due 
to the sheer amount of food required to feed animals only to have them 
killed. It is still within every person's power (I say 'every' loosely 
here) to cease eating animal products.

+lorny200 You're sort of missing my point.

"Meat-eating" /= "healthy" by default.  Most carnists eat shitty diets full 
of nutritional deficiencies that promote degenerative diseases.  They may 
assume that the mere fact they eat  meat covers their nutritional bases, 
but they are wrong.

Most vegans also eat shitty diets, but their shitty diets promote different 
health problems than carnist diets.

The typical carnist diet is just as unhealthy as the typical vegan diet, 
only in different ways.

Being healthy as a carnist or as a vegan takes dedication, discipline, and 
research.  The amount of those things necessary to be a healthy vegan is 
not more than is necessary to be a healthy carnist.

So, your family's fears about anemia among vegetarians may or may not be 
valid, depending on what kind of veg*n diet you  propose to eat.  But, THEY 
are NOT healthier simply because they eat meat.  If they don't exercise 
regularly (and vigorously), don't track macronutrients, and don't practice 
portion control or some other method of limiting their intake of saturated 
fat and cholesterol, then they are in for a rude health awakening of their 
own someday.

+Barry Sabahat   "Morality can not be a proper test because it is a 
subjective standard."

This is a common misconception that needs to be dispelled. 

Morality is a concept applicable exclusively to sentient behaviour and the 
treatment of other sentient things. This is why you cannot do anything to a 
rock that can be considered moral or immoral. The absolute foundation of 
morality is the treatment of things that have the capacity to be treated, 
or mistreated, in accordance with their interests. This is an indisputable, 
objective fact.

Now that we have identified the foundation we can determine the objective 
truth. You can say that morals are subjective, and this is certainly true; 
you may feel it is immoral to stab a human in the foot but okay to stab the 
foot of a cow. However, we can locate the foundation. Why are you against 
stabbing a human? What is the fundamental reason? 

The answer is because that person would feel a lot of pain from being 
stabbed. They have an interest in avoiding painful experiences.

You could argue that it is simply illegal and the only thing stopping you 
from stabbing them is the threat of prison, but then you would still be 
acknowledging that the foundation of your morals are to avoid infringement 
on someone's interests; that someone just happens to be you.

All sentient behaviour is rooted in interests. These interests are 
capacities: capacities to feel pain and pleasure and any other feeling that 
falls into the spectrum of consciousness. The concept of morality deals 
exclusively with treating everything in accordance with the capacities they 
possess. It's why morality is not applicable to the action of hitting a 
baseball with a bat, but is applicable to hitting a dog or human. The 
baseball has no interest in not being hit, the dog and human do. The 
interest to avoid pain is the same whether it is in a human, or a dog, or a 
cow. As long as something has an interest, it has the capacity for 
treatment or mistreatment. The concept of morality acknowledges this 
distinction and from that we can determine what is moral and immoral.

That is the objective foundation and the logic behind it. Somewhere along 
the road someone confused morals with morality, and concluded that since 
morals are subjective the concept of morality must be also. This is 
incorrect.

"Be that as it may, the nutritional need of the "eater" is the eater's 
problem and not the foods.  So if morality is the test, no living tissue 
should be consumed because it is at some level immoral."

+boosie007666 You have confused subject and object. It is impossible to 
ascertain whether or not an animal's actions are intentional, subconscious, 
or purposeful. I understand that all primates have the capacity to be 
omnivorous, because they can digest both plant and animal matter and this 
is clearly demonstrated when they sometimes eat the body of a deceased 
family member. I suspect that the only criteria they consider is, "can I 
eat that?" Yes! The ability to "eat" is not the first and front property of 
the criteria. A diet consisting of seeds, for example, would be sustained 
with insects if seeds became unavailable, as the constitution and chemical 
makeup of seeds and insects is incredibly similar.

A deer would be considered a herbivore, but from time to time they will eat 
ants. A koala will sometimes eat their parasites. Does that make these 
animals omnivorous? No. The order an animal specialist would use is to 
consider the whole of the species majority form of consumption. This 
criteria is not a strict or pedantic order. It would not be helpful 
shorthand to use the premise of intent, or even action. If that was the 
sole premise, all animals at some time or another would have to be 
considered omnivorous. I feed my cat a vegetarian diet, and is therefore a 
herbivore by action. She is completely healthy and can clearly digest her 
food, but she is still a carnivore, regardless of what she consumes. It 
would be disproportionate to consider her, an individual, and exclude the 
feline history and principal item in that history.

Well, this is in large part a question of semantics. Most vegans have 
companion animals (at least all the ones I've met), and we care for them 
deeply.  The difference is we don't view them as our property.

The main issue with pet "ownership" is that BUYING an animal, especially 
from a pet store, perpetuates an industry whose treatment of animals is 
rarely better than a factory farm (seriously, look up puppy and kitten 
mills sometime,,, it's horrific).  When we make animals into commodities, 
we will treat them as commodities first and animals second.

Adopting an animal from a shelter, or rescuing an animal in need off the 
street, however, is different, and most vegans are OK with this. 

And vegans aren't the only ones urging people to adopt rather than buy 
companion animals; lots of meat-eaters object to the pet industry, too, 
because of its atrocious record on confinement and treatment.

above those that you qualify as inferior or lower in the hierarchy of the

axiomatically label non-human animals as being less than, unequal, or 
inferior you will predictably not observe this as relativistic. If an 
advanced race of alien beings landed on Earth, they would scan the

consider your death as being incomparable to one of their own kind.

notion that humanity is intrinsically superior or that humanity is somehow 
more valuable than non-humans.

Hey everyone! I've studied nutrition at masters level at a top UK 
university for 5 years. I can tell you, from the sum total of every study 
i've witnessed, read & been a part of has shown, scientifically, that the 
vegan diet is MASSIVELY flawed, both dietarily & environmentally. Human's 
can survive without animal products, but we thrive with animal products. 
Eat your eggs (pasteurised), eat your meat (grass fed) YOUR BODY NEEDS IT. ﻿

+TheVeganAtheist (Vegans please read) Ok, so here is my complete thesis 
into why being Vegan is a flawed concept (side note - I have studied 
nutrition at masters level at a top Uk uni, i've also studied dietary 
history & evolutionary biology) I apologise if this gets a bit lengthy. 

Veganism is a deeply flawed concept, both environmentally & dietarily and 
future generation will laugh at this stupid diet, why? 

1) Veganism is a flawed concept. Why? Vegans, amongst other reasons, don't 
eat animal products to avoid the death of animals. But agriculture destroys 
more animals and the environment more than any other method. Growing 
tropical fruits destroys rain forests, shipped from across the planet. Is 
this really sustainable? A single cow can feed a family for a year if 
frozen correctly. Vegan ruins the environment more than ANY OTHER DIET! 

2) Guess what? Over 70% of the foods we eat today did not exist before the 
industrial revolution. From an evolutionary perspective, there is simply no 
way for our bodies to know what to do with these “foods” (which, as we all 
know, aren’t real food at all) If you're from Europe, is it preferable in 
your genetic makeup to eat bananas that grow in the rainforest???? 

3) Broken down by nutrient ratios, what we feed cattle (that isn't grass 
fed/pasteurised) to “fatten them up” is almost identical to the 
government-sanctioned food pyramid for a “healthy” diet! Is it any wonder 
we are in the middle of an obesity epidemic?? 

4) It was only when we started eating animal foods/fish that our brains 
doubled in size, this is a proven scientific fact, allowing for the modern 
human and all our advances. Interesting irony that the very capacity for 
making an argument for a plant-based diet comes from our ancestors’ move 
away from a plant-based diet! Ah, evolution wins EVERY time!!!!!!!!!

5) A recent Australian study was done with a group of aborigine who had 
grown up in a traditional hunter gatherer environments, and then moved into 
urban environments where they adopted modern diets. Alas, lifestyles and 
(unsurprisingly) health concerns such as obesity, type 2 diabetes, and 
heart disease arose. They returned to the outback & their hunter gatherer 
ways for a seven week period. They lost 25 pounds each and all their health 
markers (insulin resistance, blood pressure, cholesterol levels ect) 
normalised. Red meat, poultry, vegetables and seasonal fruits where 
plentiful for these men, I wonder what this study proves???

6) Another interesting point, are humans digestive tracts designed to eat 
meat?? Vegans say no, other people with working brains say YES - it turns 
out that much differs among animals, the markers lay in the composition of 
the digestive tract! Animals have evolved digestive tracts and livers to 
transform diverse food inputs into the uniform set of nutrients that they 
need for optimal health. Herbivores have foregut organs such as rumens or 
hindgut chambers for fermenting carbohydrates, turning them into fats and 
volatile acids that can be used to manufacture fats. Carnivores have livers 
capable of turning protein into glucose and fat.The truth is that humans 
are omnivores, despite what some vegan proponents would have you believe. 
We function best eating BOTH animals and plant together!!!! (Great study - 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10702160) 

7) Guess what? Meat/fish is VERY nutritious!! Did you know, that high 
quality, unprocessed meat is among the most nutritious foods in the world?! 
A 100 gram portion (3.5 ounces) of raw ground beef contains large amounts 
of Vitamin B12, B3 (Niacin), B6, Iron, Zinc, Selenium and plenty of other 
vitamins and minerals (
http://nutritiondata.self.com/facts/beef-products/6193/2) Vitamin B12 is 
particularly important because it can not be obtained in ANY amount from 
plants (arguably some sea veggies contain small traces) Studies show that 
most vegans who don’t supplement with B12, 92% are deficient in this 
critical nutrient (http://www.nutritionj.com/content/9/1/10)
Unprocessed meat is also loaded with healthy fats, but meat from grass-fed 
animals contains up to 5 times as much Omega-3 as meat from grain-fed 
animals!!!! (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18641180) But the nutrient 
composition of meat goes WAY beyond all the macro- and micronutrients that 
we are all familiar with! - CREATINE forms an energy reserve in the muscles 
and brain and is found only in animal foods. Vegetarians are deficient in 
creatine, leading to reduced physical and mental performance (
http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=8207518) 
CARNOSINE functions as a powerful anti-oxidant and provides protection 
against many degenerative processes. Carnosine is only found in animal 
foods (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15872311) DHA and EPA are the 
active forms of Omega-3 in the human body and found primarily in animal 
foods. The body is inefficient at converting ALA (the plant form of 
Omega-3) to the active forms (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11083485)

8) Humans have been eating fish for millions of years, some cultures 
SURVIVE solely on fish and have zero disease. Studies show that regular 
consumption of fish fights

Alzheimer's 
Polyunsaturated fatty acids found in many fish may prevent damage to brain 
cells. Eating fish can also dramatically reduce the risk of high blood 
pressure, which is linked with dementia. A French study of 2000 people 
showed that those who ate seafood at least once a week had a significantly 
lower risk of dementia over a seven-year period than those who didn't.

Cancer
A Swedish study of 6000 men over a 30-year period showed that those who 
didn't eat any fish had between double and treble the risk of developing 
prostate cancer, compared to those who ate moderate or large amounts. 
Shellfish, such as crab and lobster, also contains selenium, thought to 
have cancer-fighting properties.

Depression
It's been reported that fish can help to ease depression. Again, it's down 
to omega-3 fatty acids, which are believed to raise levels of the brain 
chemical serotonin.

Arthritis
Population groups that eat a lot of fish - Inuits in Greenland, for example 
- have low rates of inflammatory conditions such as arthritis. Studies have 
also shown fish oils to be useful in relieving the symptoms of rheumatoid 
arthritis.

Social benefits
According to research carried out in Mauritius, children given lots of fish 
from the age of three are less likely to have criminal records by the time 
they reach 23.

EVEN Skin
According to dermatologist Nicholas Perricone, author of The Perricone 
Prescription, a salmon-packed diet can help smooth out age lines.

We haven't tested the vegan diet long term, I would bet all the money in

Synthetic meat, in and of itself, is alright, in my opinion. The obvious 
idea is that humans will no longer choose to buy meat that came from a 
living animal over a meat culture grown in a lab. With the current human 
thought in place right now, though, many humans will still opt for the 
"real" meat, because they literally feel 0 obligation to accommodate the 
interests of nonhumans. If you want to see an interesting discussion about 
this topic, don't ask a vegan; ask a meat-eater! I have and the responses 
will make you understand just how irrationally speciesist the general 
population is.

Either way, the human population is going to require a paradigm shift, 
regardless of synthetic meat or not, if they're going to give up on 
needlessly using nonhuman animals. With synthetic meats, the justification 
for killing them becomes all that much weaker, but then again most of those 
same people already go to the grocery store, notice affordable vegan meats, 
and still go for the "real" stuff anyway. Think of all the entertainment we 
have in our lives today that we never had before, yet for some reason, 
humans still line up to see bears being whipped while they ride bicycles, 
elephants stabbed so they do a headstand, bulls stabbed to death in a ring, 
and any number of other animals confined in cages so we can gawk at them. 
Synthetic meat won't change any of that, it'll just give animal rights 
activists one more reason to show how humans don't need to hurt animals to 
live happy, healthy lives.

There are two statements in your response to the first comment, which I 
find not to be wholly convincing. 
The first one is the notion that there are no differences in the potential 
to suffer. This is something that is clearly tied to neurology, as pretty 
much anyone has to admit who concedes that there is a difference between 
squashing a fly and a puppy. While the extent may be debatable, it is clear 
that differences exist and should thus be reflected in our moral approach.
The second problem I have, is with the question of how to legislate 
sensible animal rights laws. The fact that this may be difficult in detail 
and that there will never be a 100% adherence rate to the laws does not in 
any way diminish the point of the comment. This is simply a point that 
could be raised to attack any legislation, because many are problematic in 
detail, none are perfect and there is never a 100% adherence rate. ( One 
could for example say: But how do you enforce laws against murder in a 
species which is, to a good degree, motivated by aggression?)

Over all, I believe your moral argument to rest heavily upon the idea that 
the production of plants for human consumption does not  entail any animal 
suffering or death. This is not true and a common byproduct of lopsided 
research. Plant production, especially in mono-cultures, has quite a high 
rate of animal casualties due to destruction of habitat, dietary needs of 
the animals and the use of harvesting machines. ﻿

Contrary to what is perpetuated by the dairy industries, cow milk does not 
efficiently supply your body with calcium. Milk contains animal protein 
which is highly acidic, and to neutralize the acidifying effect your body 
has to draw calcium from your bones. Once it's been used it's excreted 
through your urine. This is why the countries with the highest dairy 
intakes (America, UK, Sweden and Finland) also have the highest rates of 
osteoporosis. Here's a good 5 minute article that's worth reading:

http://foodmatters.tv/articles-1/the-truth-about-calcium-and-osteoporosis 

There are many vegan calcium sources that aren't counterproductive to your 
bone health, and plant calcium sources also contain vitamins for bone 
health not found in milk (but not spinach. The oxalic acid binds the 
calcium to the food and it isn't absorbed well). Here's a good list.

http://www.care2.com/greenliving/25-vegan-sources-for-calcium.html?page=2

The recommended intake varies from 700mg in the UK to 1000mg in the US to 
300mg in India. Just aim for 500mg+ and you'll be doing better than most, 
especially those who consume animal protein.

The attempt to provide a genuinely non-anthropocentric set of values, or 
preferences seems to be a hopeless quest. Once we eschew all human values, 
interests and preferences we are confronted with just too many

billion year time scale. The problem with the various non-anthropocentric 
bases for value which have been proposed is that they permit too many 
different possibilities, not all of which are at all congenial to us. And 
that matters. We should be concerned to promote a rich, diverse and vibrant 
biosphere. Human flourishing may certainly be included as a legitimate part 
of such a flourishing.The preoccupations of deep ecology arise as a result

Sure, lots of vegans don't like meat or the idea of eating  meat, but that 
does not mean they lack rational reasons for that emotional response.

The case against meat is fairly simple:

A) Almost every ethical philosophy agrees that it is wrong to kill or harm 
animals without sufficient justification, and most of those philosophies 
have good, rational reasons for agreeing to this; and,

B) Humans living in modern society have no nutritional need to eat animals, 
regardless of whether their ancestors did, or whether people living in 
primitive societies do; therefore,

C) It is wrong to eat animals because most modern people just do so out of 
habit or taste, which do not trump a sentient being's interest in not being 
killed unjustly.

That's it.  No emotional response is required, but they are always 
unavoidable.

It's the meat-eaters who have the irrational, faith-based argument here.

There is nothing wrong with using an emotional or visceral response as the 
starting point for a rational position.  Reason and emotion are not 
opposites, and are impossible to separate anyway.  The danger of emotion is 
that it can cloud judgment, but if it can be rationally supported, then it 
is valid.

Anyway, my point is that the whole "what about plants?" tactic elides the 
real issue of animal suffering, which is what  it is designed to do.  In a 
way, it's doing exactly what you're trying to expose: rationalizing an 
emotional response that isn't reasonable.  In this case, emotional response

wrong."  Then, fishing for rationalization: "but what about plants?"

It's just an excuse, much more than it is a valid hypothetical.

+HumaneHominid I understand that hypothetical situations CAN be a "waste of 
time and energy". But I also find that hypothetical situations can usefully 
peel away rational defences or support to find true reasons for beliefs. 
Many people choose a belief or way of life based on an emotional or 
visceral response, and then seek the "rational" reasons for their belief.

An aside as an example: Many Christians I meet will use philosophical, 
scientific, or historical arguments to support their theism. However, they 
all came to their religion for cultural or emotional reasons and use these 
new arguments to defend the true reasons for their views on reality. When 
you whittle away their intellectual arguments with hypotheticals or 
contrary evidence you are left with belief because "I know it in my heart." 
or "I have felt His presence in my life."

energy, since there is no evidence that plants are sentient, and no 
rational reason to think any new discoveries about plant physiology are 
likely to overturn that view.

In short, it's a question designed, perhaps not by you personally, but by 
the minds who first conceived it in dialogue with vegans, to avoid the real 
issue.

Hypotheticals can be fun, but they are a distraction where real-world 
ethics are concerned.

+TheVeganAtheist (Vegans please read) Ok, so here is my complete thesis 
into why being Vegan is a flawed concept (side note - I have studied 
nutrition at masters level at a top Uk uni, i've also studied dietary 
history & evolutionary biology) I apologise if this gets a bit lengthy. 

Veganism is a deeply flawed concept, both environmentally & dietarily and 
future generation will laugh at this stupid diet, why? 

1) Veganism is a flawed concept. Why? Vegans, amongst other reasons, don't 
eat animal products to avoid the death of animals. But agriculture destroys 
more animals and the environment more than any other method. Growing 
tropical fruits destroys rain forests, shipped from across the planet. Is 
this really sustainable? A single cow can feed a family for a year if 
frozen correctly. Vegan ruins the environment more than ANY OTHER DIET! 

2) Guess what? Over 70% of the foods we eat today did not exist before the 
industrial revolution. From an evolutionary perspective, there is simply no 
way for our bodies to know what to do with these “foods” (which, as we all 
know, aren’t real food at all) If you're from Europe, is it preferable in 
your genetic makeup to eat bananas that grow in the rainforest???? 

3) Broken down by nutrient ratios, what we feed cattle (that isn't grass 
fed/pasteurised) to “fatten them up” is almost identical to the 
government-sanctioned food pyramid for a “healthy” diet! Is it any wonder 
we are in the middle of an obesity epidemic?? 

4) It was only when we started eating animal foods/fish that our brains 
doubled in size, this is a proven scientific fact, allowing for the modern 
human and all our advances. Interesting irony that the very capacity for 
making an argument for a plant-based diet comes from our ancestors’ move 
away from a plant-based diet! Ah, evolution wins EVERY time!!!!!!!!!

5) A recent Australian study was done with a group of aborigine who had 
grown up in a traditional hunter gatherer environments, and then moved into 
urban environments where they adopted modern diets. Alas, lifestyles and 
(unsurprisingly) health concerns such as obesity, type 2 diabetes, and 
heart disease arose. They returned to the outback & their hunter gatherer 
ways for a seven week period. They lost 25 pounds each and all their health 
markers (insulin resistance, blood pressure, cholesterol levels ect) 
normalised. Red meat, poultry, vegetables and seasonal fruits where 
plentiful for these men, I wonder what this study proves???

6) Another interesting point, are humans digestive tracts designed to eat 
meat?? Vegans say no, other people with working brains say YES - it turns 
out that much differs among animals, the markers lay in the composition of 
the digestive tract! Animals have evolved digestive tracts and livers to 
transform diverse food inputs into the uniform set of nutrients that they 
need for optimal health. Herbivores have foregut organs such as rumens or 
hindgut chambers for fermenting carbohydrates, turning them into fats and 
volatile acids that can be used to manufacture fats. Carnivores have livers 
capable of turning protein into glucose and fat.The truth is that humans 
are omnivores, despite what some vegan proponents would have you believe. 
We function best eating BOTH animals and plant together!!!! (Great study - 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10702160) 

7) Guess what? Meat/fish is VERY nutritious!! Did you know, that high 
quality, unprocessed meat is among the most nutritious foods in the world?! 
A 100 gram portion (3.5 ounces) of raw ground beef contains large amounts 
of Vitamin B12, B3 (Niacin), B6, Iron, Zinc, Selenium and plenty of other 
vitamins and minerals (
http://nutritiondata.self.com/facts/beef-products/6193/2) Vitamin B12 is 
particularly important because it can not be obtained in ANY amount from 
plants (arguably some sea veggies contain small traces) Studies show that 
most vegans who don’t supplement with B12, 92% are deficient in this 
critical nutrient (http://www.nutritionj.com/content/9/1/10)
Unprocessed meat is also loaded with healthy fats, but meat from grass-fed 
animals contains up to 5 times as much Omega-3 as meat from grain-fed 
animals!!!! (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18641180) But the nutrient 
composition of meat goes WAY beyond all the macro- and micronutrients that 
we are all familiar with! - CREATINE forms an energy reserve in the muscles 
and brain and is found only in animal foods. Vegetarians are deficient in 
creatine, leading to reduced physical and mental performance (
http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=8207518) 
CARNOSINE functions as a powerful anti-oxidant and provides protection 
against many degenerative processes. Carnosine is only found in animal 
foods (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15872311) DHA and EPA are the 
active forms of Omega-3 in the human body and found primarily in animal 
foods. The body is inefficient at converting ALA (the plant form of 
Omega-3) to the active forms (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11083485)

8) Humans have been eating fish for millions of years, some cultures 
SURVIVE solely on fish and have zero disease. Studies show that regular 
consumption of fish fights

Alzheimer's 
Polyunsaturated fatty acids found in many fish may prevent damage to brain 
cells. Eating fish can also dramatically reduce the risk of high blood 
pressure, which is linked with dementia. A French study of 2000 people 
showed that those who ate seafood at least once a week had a significantly 
lower risk of dementia over a seven-year period than those who didn't.

Cancer
A Swedish study of 6000 men over a 30-year period showed that those who 
didn't eat any fish had between double and treble the risk of developing 
prostate cancer, compared to those who ate moderate or large amounts. 
Shellfish, such as crab and lobster, also contains selenium, thought to 
have cancer-fighting properties.

Depression
It's been reported that fish can help to ease depression. Again, it's down 
to omega-3 fatty acids, which are believed to raise levels of the brain 
chemical serotonin.

Arthritis
Population groups that eat a lot of fish - Inuits in Greenland, for example

also shown fish oils to be useful in relieving the symptoms of rheumatoid

Social benefits
According to research carried out in Mauritius, children given lots of fish

EVEN Skin
According to dermatologist Nicholas Perricone, author of The Perricone

The current surplus of food is not being effectively distributed because it 
is not monetarily viable. The distribution networks in developing countries 
are notoriously unreliable, and the consumers can rarely afford any of the 
produce. So the industries conclude that they can make more profit by 
ignoring those countries and focus on selling most of their crops to the 
livestock industry. 

Now, if the livestock industry was abolished, the interest in supplying to 
those countries would no longer be an imposition, but a profitable 
necessity. Without livestock to take 50% of their grain and 70% of their 
soy, they will need to source those surpluses to other outlets to close the 
profit margin. This will open up a huge market between the first world and 
the developing societies. Distribution would be a top priority, the produce 
would be cheap to accommodate the developing economies, and within a 
reasonable timeframe there would be a thriving intercontinental market, and 
we would be well on our way to curing world hunger for good.

The vegan cause is often harmed by vegans themselves. The only valid 
argument (I'm not saying it's not important) in their favor is the moral 
aspect of animal welfare. They should focus solely on that, because nobody 
can possibly take the nutritionist argument seriously, not even "dumb meat 
eaters". In short you can certainly say eating meat is immoral (it's hard 
to argue against that), but you can't say under no circumstances that 
carnivorous diet is unhealthy. Or even preposterously suggest that humans 
have evolved as vegetarians. It puts people off.

Meat based or at least meat containing diet is much easier to fit the needs 
of the human body (a typical omnivore, like most animals including pigs and 
chicken). That is not to say it's impossible to have an entirely vegan 
diet, but it's certainly not easy and requires a lot of knowledge about 
nutrients, essential amino acids etc. It would also require a variety of 
different crops to be consumed daily to ensure enough protein and to 
include all essential amino acids. Not to mention that a lot of people have 
allergies to different plant proteins and most people don't digest all 
plant proteins easily (a clear relic of our evolution). It's impossible for 
all people to be vegetarians or vegan. This misleading and misrepresenting 
of what being a vegetarian (or vegan) is repulses even the people that take 
the real moral problem of killing animals seriously. It's an insult.

Ruminants and equids as "perfect" vegetarians basically consume bacterias 
of their intestines at least as much as the plant material itself. That is 
why they are even able to be vegetarian or should I say "prokaryoterian". 
Humans can't do it directly (well we do but we can't do it exclusively), we 
don't have the intestines for it. To solve the moral problem of killing 
animals without pretending to be vegetarian, we could use biotechnology and 
harvest the bacterial biomass (not unlike "vegetarian" animals). It would 
even be scalable, since huge bioreactors are already widely used, not to 
mention cheap as well as a lot more environmentally friendly.﻿

I thought I'd attempt a better defense of meat consumption. First, a simple 
biological note that with the existence of canine teeth in our bodies and 
the fact that our digestive tracts directly represent that of an omnivore 
shows that we are tuned toward an equally meat/plant diet. Added to this 
fact is the evidence presented by concerns in space travel. Defecation in 
space is... well... a sticky subject. In order to try and solve this, a 
minimum diet of meat was tried because it produced less waste as the body 
easily used up all the nutrients while plant matter takes longer to digest 
and this inefficiency obviously produces more waste product. Meat in a 
minimal - so, you know, not the usual US quantity - amount is an easy and 
efficient source of nutrients, proteins - milk especially has some 
important proteins - and calories.

Now, I do agree with the issue of sentient beings needing to be taken out 
of the equation, but with the possible perfection of stem cell use, insect 
proteins, and 3D printing, there is a possible source of meat that could be 
completely killing free and industrialized to support a large user base. 
Add education of appropriate diet including more plant life and I see no 
reason why meat eating and ethics couldn't coexist.

The real concern with this is that the hunting clans won't want to embrace 
this, kind of like car fanatics who need to speed and rev their engines not 
wanting the quiet alternative of ecological vehicles. We can have our cake 
and eat it too if the macho pricks of the world could detract from their 
ego. I wish I could be more political about that... but no. No excuse for 
this machismo parading.

I am a lacto-ovo vegetarian. I see no problem with raising animals for food 
as long as the food we obtain from them does not necessitate their living

profit to warp and corrupt this relationship, treating our fellow sentient 
creatures as objects to be exploited and discarded. This is why I abhor 
milk, eggs, and other animal products obtained from factory farms.﻿

I personally am a meat eater and I know that animals feel pain and deserve 
every right as humans, because lets face it, we are animals whether we like 
it or not. It shouldn't matter about the intellect of an animal. I love and 
respect animals and would never harm one (except for certain insects such 
as mosquitoes and flies). For a long time I have tried to go vegan but

I am meant to be an omnivore, and that animals also eat animals too. I try 
to buy meat that was raised naturally and humanly but I am 17 and not 
financially independent and my parents go cheap too much and buy 
conventionally raised meat :(﻿

It's great that you are ethically conflicted about this, it says a lot 
about your character. However, the truth is that by purchasing and eating 
meat you are just as, if not more responsible for the harm that is 
inflicted on animals. The industries and the people who work in them are 
disgustingly unethical, and I certainly judge them as worse people than the 
average consumer; but none of those industries would exist if consumers 
weren't paying them to keep doing what they do. The supply only exists 
because of the demand. It can be hard to see things for how they really are 
because society is good at manipulating and conditioning people, but you're 
already more aware than most.

As for your meat cravings, this is often due to a poor transition into a 
meat-free diet. Meat is dense in protein and often fat, so if you aren't 
properly satiated you are wired to crave things that provide immediate 
energy for survival. If you structure your diet a bit more carefully to 
make up for the removal of meat your temptations will likely be suppressed 
significantly. There are also meat substitutes available which many 
vegetarians and vegans enjoy, so these would be an ideal way to transition 
into the lifestyle.

And of course, meat is an addiction. It can be hard to give up initially 
because it is often such a large part of your lifestyle and radical change 
is often daunting. You really need to make the veg*n mindset YOUR mindset, 
in that whenever you see meat you think about how it used to be part of an 
innocent creature that was brought into this world to suffer. Then you need 
to ask yourself if your taste buds are more important than that.

Humanely raised beef is simply an oxymoron, especially in retail 
supermarkets and butchers. This is a billion dollar industry and there will 
always be compromises to animal welfare made in the name of profit. There 
is nothing humane about raising an innocent sentient creature with the sole 
intent of killing it to make money.

A vegan diet is usually no more expensive than a meat-based one, assuming 
you shop smart and don't buy too much processed vegan foods (vegan ice 
creams and chocolates are more expensive, but if anything this just 
encourages you to cut back on junk food). And veggies by themselves can be 
rather bland, but there are so many great recipes available online. I'm not 
sure how your parents are in the kitchen, but vegan recipes can often have 
less ingredients than their meat-based counterparts.

Living at home could be an issue, but you said you've tried to eliminate 
meat in the past so I'm assuming they accommodated you during those times. 
If you decide to give it another go, just be very clear on your reasons and 
perhaps request that they try to refrain from consuming meat so openly 
around you during your initial phases of trying to kick the habit. 
Hopefully they will be understanding to this. 

I do hope you try again. I think you want to by posting about it here, but 
just needed a bit of advice to make the attempt less daunting than it may 
have been last time. I hope I was helpful, and good luck.

The dairy and egg industries are just as unethical, if not more so than the 
meat industry. Female cows are raped and their calves are taken from them 
at birth. If the calf is a male it is sent to be slaughtered. If it is a 
female it is fed growth hormones and locked in a confined stall while a 
machine drains 10 times the amount of milk they normally produce. This 
often leads to mastitis, brittle bones due to calcium depletion, and 
lameness.

And after around 4 years, they become too exhausted to efficiently produce 
milk and are sent to be slaughtered. The egg industry is no different, the 
males are gassed, ground up and suffocated. The females are debeaked and 
locked in confined areas, even in "free range" farms where they are still

Slaughter and suffering happen in every facet of the animal produce

I am not setting any hierarchy of importance, I am acknowledging that it is 
impossible to survive without causing damage, and when there is no need to 
cause damage to survive, there is only one logical, ethical choice to make. 
"Drawing lines under what is an acceptable death for convenience sake"? No,

I live in an apartment at the moment, so I am unable to grow my own food. 
It is not unethical to do what is necessary to survive when you are not 
intentionally killing other living beings. The death toll from agriculture 
is unfortunate but it is not intentional. You do not grow crops with the 
direct goal of killing animals. You grow crops with the goal of growing 
crops. Ethics are defined by intent.

As I have already said, if an animal has an interest in staying alive, you 
have no right to infringe upon that interest, unless of course in 
situations where they are infringing upon your own interest to stay alive 
(being attacked by a lion etc). Whether it is painless is irrelevant when

I didn't say vegetarians were more ethical than vegans, just that I find

Your argument re meat eaters killing more animals is illogical. I'm gonna 
make some assumptions on numbers here. If a meat eater has a diet of say 
2000 calories, and she gets 1000 calories from meat which kills 1 animal + 
say 20 insects, and the rest from vegetables that kill 5 insects per 100 
calories then they've killed 71 individual life forms.
A vegan eating 2000 calories kills 100 insects. If there isn't a hierarchy 
of importance then the vegan is just killing more animals.

So now we're setting up hierarchies of importance and drawing lines under 
what is an acceptable death for convenience sake. As you point out, you can 
eat home grown stuff killing far fewer insects than industrial farming 
does, so does that make you an unethical monster at the moment? I say that 
this importance is based on complexity, especially it's social complexity. 
To me, killing something in as painless a way as possible (I know factory 
farming doesn't do this though) that doesn't have an understanding of 
'self' isn't that big an issue unless something else in it's social 
structure is going to suffer significantly because of that (see your own 
cow example). The more complex the creature's understanding of itself, and 
it's social structure, the less ethical killing it becomes - to the point 
where I don't think can justify it at all for Elephants, Dolphins etc. even

I put spiders in cups and put them outside too. Though I kill them in their

doesn't bother me.

Rights are a societal construct. What matters, what is the foundation of 
all sentience, is interests. If something has interests, then having those 
interests infringed upon is an unpleasant, often painful experience. 

"To conclude that anything that looks like it has our emotions must share 
them is jumping to conclusions."

True, but it is the logical conclusion. To claim that animals don't possess 
characteristics when all observable evidence suggests that they do is the 
illogical conclusion.

"By that logic, spiders have the same rights as humans and any sort of 
farming is mass murder."

Spiders certainly have interests, and these should not be infringed upon. 
If there is a spider in my house I will put a glass over it and move it 
outside. As for the agricultural death toll, it is a tragedy, and I am 
planning to move to a primarily home-grown diet where I have direct control 
over the growing methods. However, as I stated, simply being alive causes 
destruction and the goal is to minimize it. Our population has become so 
overwhelming that agriculture is a necessity, and it is one of the many 
necessary acts of survival that results in unintentional loss of life. This 
is tragic and unfortunate, but it is nigh on impossible to live a life 
without leaving a trail of damage in your wake. We must, however, take 
measures to ensure that damage is at a minimum, and this means not 
supporting an industry that exists solely with the intent of killing 
innocent beings to make profit from an unnecessary and ultimately unhealthy 
habit.

"You're setting a line too - you're just setting it lower than perhaps I am 
and some others do."

Actually I am not setting any subjective line, but rather acknowledging a 
conscious being's interests and not supporting the direct infringement upon 
them. I am rejecting subjectivity and treating all life according to how 
evidence suggests they can be affected by that treatment.

"Ethics is a branch of philosophy - not science."

Ethics is a philosophy that can be defined through evidence, which is what 
I am doing. Your initial philosophical question was whether an animal's 
observable behaviour was to be taken at face value, which I would say 
absolutely, because that is the evidence we have (along with vast bodies of 
scientific research). So yes, when a living being's welfare is in question, 
we must act in accordance with evidence, not philosophical theory.

"Vegetable farming absolutely kills more individual life forms than

 I made no mention of grass fed beef, and a meat eater's lifestyle does not

possess the intellect required to vote or run for political office, 
therefore it has no interests in those things, and there is no need to give 
them voting rights. However, a cow certainly has an interest to continue 
living, and this must be taken into consideration when dealing with it. 
Different species possess different capacities, and how we treat them 
should be determined by those capacities. It's why I can eat a plant, 
because they have no interest in not being eaten. And it's why I shouldn't 
kill an animal, because they have an interest in not being killed.

4. Most vegans do not claim that all life is equal. The point is that if 
there is absolutely no need to kill something, you shouldn't. There is 
absolutely no need for meat, so why are we killing 56 billion land animals 
per year for what is totally unnecessary? 

We cause destruction just by being alive. If I go for a walk, chances are 
I'll step on an ant or two. The point is to minimize it. When we can 
survive perfectly healthily without slaughtering innocent creatures, who in 
their right mind would slaughter them anyway?

Firstly, I'm not particularly worried about very brief experiences of pain. 
What concerns me is suffering. Memory of pain, and empathy with friends who 
suffer pain - or even the suffering of animals that loose someone in their 
social network concern me.

To be clear, I don't condone torture of animals if it can at all be avoided.

As for killing and suffering, there are philosophical and pragmatic answers 
to that.

Philosophically, does a creature experience suffering - not pain, but 
suffering - by losing something? If they have little to no understanding of 
itself, can it worry about death? Does it suffer if someone in it's family 
dies? What about if whole colonies are murdered by insecticide in 
traditional vegetable farming, or by introduced predators in alternative / 
sustainable farming?

Pragmatically speaking, we can't really test a creatures ability to suffer 
without a shared understanding of it's experience. The more like us an 
animal thinks, the more confidently we can say it suffers in the way we do.

You really have to draw a line somewhere, because some plants have 
rudimentary reactions to their environment. You also have to create a 
hierarchy - it's the only way even veganism makes sense. Farming of 
vegetables kills roughly the same or more individual lives than farming 
meat (depending on the meat). However, the farming of vegetables kills 
worms and insects - while pork kills a whole pig. Surely the objection is 
that the pig's life is more important as it's a more complex / intelligent 
life form?

Why is intelligence your only determinant in the value of a life? 
Intelligence has nothing to do with the capacity to feel pain. And it has 
nothing to do with an individual's desire to live.

share your opinion are stupid, makes me question your intellect. First off

Hello everyone, I am responding to @Graham Frost who disabled his reply. I 
have read over these points and was interested in learning more.
I will address these in the same order:

1) While it is true the agriculture destroys land, often habitats of 
animals, this is a necessary thing the human species must do to survive. I 
do strongly believe we have a responsibility to reduce the destruction of 
the world for out needs. It should be noted that most agriculture 
development in the world (around 65%) is used for animal productions. it 
should also be noted that production of animals accounts for more CO2 
production than transport WORLDWIDE. It also contributes a significant 37% 
of methane production, a gas that has more than 10 times the potency on 
climate change than CO2. Livestock’s share in nitrous oxide emissions is 
65%. Livestock are also responsible for almost two-thirds (64 percent) of 
anthropogenic ammonia emissions, which contribute significantly to acid 
rain and acidification of ecosystems. Truth is that it takes more land to 
produce the same amount of protein for meat than compared to plant matter.
http://www.fao.org/docrep/010/a0701e/a0701e00.htm

2) I'm not sure if this is correct, but I'll assume it is anyhow. While if 
it is true that such foods did not exist, they make up the same basic 
element of fruit. The body has a universal way of dealing with food, it 
breaks it down into its constituent parts and ultimately sees no difference 
of how this food was originally formulated. So, say for example I have 
never eaten a durian, my body breaks it down and sees amino acids, vitamins 
and minerals and many familiar molecules and can use these to fuel the body.

3) While if this is true, not sure if it is. It is deeply concerning, but 
nones the less does not affect how vegans should see their diet.

4) This is one of the most common misconceptions on the planet of our 
evolution. It was not meat as a foundation that *caused* us to evolve, but 
the compact energy and nutrients it contained. Our brains were already 
evolving in our species due to our language capabilities and communication 
among our community. Meat was simply a tool to which we used to allow for 
the extra energy we needed to allow further development that the vegetation 
could not do. However, today we have a modern agriculture and worldwide 
communication structure that allows us to get the same nutrients without 
this meat, unlike back then. You could also argue that if meat is 
responsible for our advance brain capacity, why have the carnivores not 
evolved to such as stage? 

5) Again, this does not really affect any reason to not become vegan. We 
have the capacity to get the same nutrients without animal products. Also, 
it should be noted that a vegan diet also has many of the lowering health 
benefits as you mentioned. Studies have shown that while similar indigenous 
populations live on mostly meat products and little veggies, an in depth 
study on their diets concluded "The totality of reviewed evidence leads us 
to the conclusion that Eskimos have a prevalence of CAD similar to 
non-Eskimo populations, and they have excessive mortality due to 
cerebrovascular strokes, and their overall mortality is twice as high as 
that of non-Eskimo populations, and their life expectancy is approximately 
10 years shorter than the Danish population."
http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0828282X14002372﻿

This can be seen across a wide range of similar populations such as the 
Eskimos.

6) What's similar about humans and herbivores is as follows:
- Broad, flattened and spade shaped
- Short and blunt canines/none
- Flattened molars with nodular cusps
- Long and complex colons
- Flattened nails
- length of small intestine is about 10-11 times body
- Saliva has digestive enzymes
It is also indicted that humans digest plant matter easier than meat and 
will much less adverse effects. Also, while it may be convenient to eat 
meat to get your nutrients, you can get the same nutrients on a vegan diet 
with not as much effort as everyone says.

7) While fish and meat both have great sources of nutrients, like omega 3s, 
the highest source of omega 3 in in flax seed oil, 3rd highest (just below 
salmon) is chia seeds. The highest foods in omega 6s are no. 1 Vegetable 
oil, 3rd sunflower seeds. While it is convenient to have many vitamins in a 
steak, these can be found in many vegan sources in large amounts and easily 
placed into a convenient diet. Firstly, creatine is made within the body 
from its constituents which all come from plant matter. Secondly, your 
study states the following "The major finding was that after 
supplementation, the memory of vegetarians was better than that of 
meat-eaters (Fig. 1). However, at baseline, *memory did not differ 
depending on dietary style, so any hypothesised creatine deficiency in 
vegetarians did not influence memory, rather it was found that vegetarians 
were more sensitive to supplementation with creatine.*" Also they noted 
that "To date, the findings are too preliminary to allow the role of 
creatine in the brain and the impact of its supplementation on cognition to 
be established."
Now, your carnosine argument states that it's a powerful antioxidant. This 
is true, but truer is that carosine is also made within our bodies from its 
constituents, all readily available in the vegan diet. Now you DHA and EPA 
argument is also flawed because while the body is said to be 'inefficient' 
at making these amino acid chain from AHA, studies indicate that deficiency 
in these amino acids to not affect a person. "There is no evidence of 
adverse effects on health or cognitive function with lower DHA intake in 
vegetarians." http://www.plefa.com/article/S0952-3278(09)00086-6/abstract

8) 'Studies show' mmmm yes, like all the ones you're providing. Studies 
that I show such as ones seen in 5) say different.

9) Testing long term a vegan diet to my knowledge has not been done 
scientifically. However, find it anywhere, that vegan populations 
percentages have lower rates of many of the leading causes of death. I 
would bet my money that people will one day wake up to the terrible cruelty 
they're inflicting upon animals and change. Now that the bets are place, 
you can easily find that a vegan diets is gaining momentum in many 
countries. 

10) This is a subjective point and thus does not require rebuttal.﻿

Thank you, made me rage pretty hard when he left that factually incorrect 
essay and disabled replies. Debate ethics all you want, but it's flat-out 
wrong to say that veganism is environmentally irresponsible. The negative 
consequences associated with eating meat are so widely accepted by the 
scientific community that environmental science and ecology textbooks will 
often recommend that students cut back on meat intake in order to reduce 
their carbon footprint.

I fully understand your point of view, and highly agree with you on the 
basis of the depletion of the environment and the unnecessary slaughter of 
animals solely for human use. I appreciate vegans and would love to be a 
vegan. My only weakness is that I simply don't have the will power. I enjoy 
the flavour of certain types of meat, cheese and other milk products, and 
eggs, and for this I could not be a vegan. I may one day possess the will 
to stop eating meat, but it's too difficult for me, at least at this point 
in my life.﻿

While I am not a vegan or a vegetarian, I rarely eat meat or fish. In fact 
I haven't eaten fish (knowingly) for twenty years, since I found that the 
cod in my fish and chips was in fact two small codling stuck together and 
covered in batter. I remember when six foot cod hung in the fish-shop 
window, and the sea boiled with mackerel, clearly visible from the beach.
However, I am not at ease with your portrayal of meat-eaters as 'stupid', 
or your attempts to muster those who disagree by use of the 'choose this 
week's idiot' style of poll.(Although 'all the world's a dessert' nearly 
made me choke).
There is also a point that you made twice -- that animals only kill out of 
the need for certain nutrients, or because they have a limited choice of 
prey. I beg to differ -- animals kill, I believe, because it satisfies some 
instinct, and they eat what they like the taste of. They have no concept of 
'nutrients' or 'diet'. Sheep have been known to eat a passing pheasant 
chick, probably because it needs calcium -- but the sheep doesn't know 
that. It's just a walking pie.
While I sympathise with your desire to end the suffering of animals, I 
believe you are needlessly alienating those who like a bacon sandwich from 
time to time.﻿

^This
But in short:
- It takes more space to produce the meat. We would still need plants for 
both us and the animals (what would they eat otherwise?)
- Your "what would we do with the leftover animals" question assumes that 
everyone would go vegan overnight, and that is unrealistic. Gradually less 
animals would be bred because the demand for their meat would go down. 
After that point is really just speculation, but my guess is that the 
animals we once used for food would be the same as any other domestic 
animal, eg horses, cats dogs, etc.
- The lab-steak thing is very subjective and lots of vegans have many 
different opinions about it. However you could ask, if the original cells 
that are needed to grow the meat came from a human, would you eat it?

Hope that helped!

Wait, someone clarify: are plants sentient? If you use the definition as 
the ability to feel and have interests, then plants are sentient. Plants 
are very interested in spreading and preserving their genes (reproduction) 
and have developed many traits and behaviors that allow them to do so. As 
for feeling and perceiving, have you heard of thigmotropism? it is how 
plants can respond to touch. Furthermore, plants can tell when they are 
being eaten and actually change growth rates if a herbivore is present. 

Another definition included that sentient beings have preferences. I would 
argue that plants also have preferences, as each species has different 
requirements and plants often grow towards the resources they need (i.e. 
growing towards light/ roots towards water).

Am I missing a key part of this definition, or have plants always been 
sentient and you just ignored that?
Just because the plant's don't have neurons that we are familiar with 
doesn't mean that a convergent evolution has not occurred. It seems to me 
that plants can feel, perceive and act upon these sensory inputs. Is this 
not sentience?﻿

I just read the full text of the Cambridge Declaration on Consciousness. 
 It gives no clear delineation between sentient and non-sentient animals,

"Non-human animals, including all mammals and birds, and many other

The phrase "many other creatures" is extraordinarily vague.  How are we 
supposed to interpret it?  You apparently interpret it be far more

are considered sentient, then went on to specifically refer to fish as 
sentient.  I don't think you have presented adequate information to justify 
this claim.

I feel as though you're misrepresenting Darwin and evolution when you bring 
up differences in degree rather than kind.  While it applies in many cases, 
it clearly does not apply in others.  You would not say that reptiles 
possess mammary glands to a lesser degree than mammals, you would say that 
reptiles do not possess mammary glands.  You would not say that mollusks 
possess feathers to a lesser degree than birds, you would say that mollusks 
do not possess feathers.  For certain characteristics, there must be a 
point at which you can demonstrate that it either exists or does not.  I 
feel as though sentience is one of those characteristics, and that many 
animals operate on instinct and stimulus response alone.

I'm not saying your position is wrong.  There are many valid arguments in 
favor of being vegan, however the Cambridge Declaration on Consciousness 
only specifically addresses mammals, birds, and octopuses.  I think it is 
dishonest to apply it to all animals and use animal sentience as an 
argument in favor of strict veganism.﻿

You're apparently not seeing my point, +Bib Green.  What I am saying is 
that using animal sentience as a rationale for not consuming any animal 
products *at all* only makes sense if you can demonstrate that *all animals* 
are sentient.  If you acknowledge that you cannot demonstrate an animal is 
sentient, yet still refrain from using its flesh or secretions as food or 
clothing, it is dishonest to use sentience as your reason.  I don't know if 
you're being dishonest with yourself, or only being dishonest with everyone 
else.  Obviously vegans don't want to harm or unduly distress any animals *at 
all*, so sentience is *completely irrelevant*.

1. All animals in the farming industries, except for seafood, are mammals 
or birds. The Cambridge Declaration states that all mammals and birds 
possess neurological substrates for conscious awareness.

2. In regards to fish, there are vast bodies of evidence that suggest fish 
are in fact more intelligent than some land animals and their cognitive 
ability in terms of memory can even exceed primates. They practice very 
sophisticated social structures and advanced scouting techniques indicative 
of conscious thought.

As for their ability to feel pain, the consensus can be conflicting. Fish 
possess nociceptors that permit response to painful stimuli. Whether this 
is a reflex or a conscious experience is hard to verify. However, studies 
in Edinburgh on rainbow trout showed that after being subjected to injuries 
some of the fish displayed symptoms identical to post traumatic stress 
disorder in humans, such as refusing to eat and rocking back and forth as 
survivors of train accidents and earthquakes often do.

Furthermore, fish that have been captured before tend to avoid the bodies 
of water where they were caught, and angler fishing has been shown to cause 
decreases in catchability. Many fish tend to avoid places where they have 
been attacked by predators which indicates that they have interests in 
avoiding being prey.

It's possible that some animals are not conscious, however the animal 
produce industries deal exclusively with animals that have vast evidence 
for their consciousness.

I am going to posit that if an animal does not have the capacity to discern 
from right or wrong then the number of rights they should be prescribed, 
under my own judgement of course, would range from very little to none at 
all.

The reason for this position is more or less to have a more robust boundary 
for which we can discern if something deserves rights or not. As it seems, 
your answer to many of these criticisms about how animals with less 
intelligence not deserving rights is simply to state that if an animal has 
a vested interest in itself, then it deserves rights, assuming I have 
assumed your position correctly. I cannot simply agree with a standard this 
low.

Let us take the law that govern humans to illustrate a point: the law, 
generally, is made to protect the people from otherwise immoral action, 
such as protection of rights. The reason that a power might wish to enact a 
law based on morals, the thing that would discern right actions from wrong 
actions, would be, once again, for protection. Protection from what? From 
someone who has either not considered the moral ramifications of their 
actions when committing a crime, or someone who has decided that the self 
benefit from committing the crime out weighs the moral wrong attached to it.

Sure, we can say that someone who does not judge the moral weight of their 
actions but who has also not committed any crime should still have rights, 
just as we might say a sociopath shouldn't be condemned for nothing. On the 
other hand, someone who does not have full mental faculties is usually 
considered to be either less than human, or someone who requires certain 
amount of care. What's more, is that when a human doesn't have empathy, we 
could consider curing that as an alternative.

When you take an entire species not designed to have certain mental 
faculties such as discerning right from wrong, there is no such alternative 
to stripping their rights that will not be fruitless. It's not to say that 
they cannot be trusted to stop themselves from committing a heinous act, 
but by giving them rights that would otherwise allow them to do such 
things, we are endangering ourselves and doing very little to advance 
society as a whole.

tl;dr : if animals can't into moral and we lock up people who can't into 
moral, why do animals deserve rights?
