Since you don't preface with what you believe it's hard it's hard to take 
the comments into context. If you believe that the consumption of honey is 
immoral and damaging to the ecosystem then I must say that is an ignorant 
comment. I already know how honey was made and no it does not disgust me 
one bit (what that even has to do with the ethics of consuming honey I 
don't know, seems like a big red herring that non sequitur to me). How 
could caring for bees in order to consume left over honey and use their wax 
possibly be immoral? Insects have basically no mental capacity whatsoever  
to experience emotion and unlike higher order animals are pretty much 
biological machines. Even if they were arguably treated poorly (in the 
objective sense that their treatment is not conducive to their 
prosperity) their lack of capacity to understand their maltreatment makes 
the issue of moral treatment dicey at best.

As far as cow's milk: I assume your argument is that cows can be treated 
poorly on some farms and that is unethical. Well, sure, but it is a 
complete non sequitur argument to then say that the consumption of milk is 
immoral unless it is the rule that cows are treated poorly and not the 
exception. And even if it were the rule that cows were treated poorly it 
would only be immoral to facilitate their treatment by keeping the farmers 
in business through buying their products and would not make the 
consumption itself immoral. The issue would be how the farmers treat the 
cows.

To the issue as a whole: since not everyone is capable of becoming a vegan 
due to lack of resources (whether that be monetary or being unable to 
replace the nutrients) it can not be said that it is immoral to consume 
animals. Morality is subjective and therefore subject to the consensus of 
others. Since the overwhelming majority of people find it perfectly 
acceptable to kill an animal for sustenance it can not be said that it is 
immoral. You can say that you don't agree with it but you it wrong to call 
into question the ethics of those who have a different opinion. No one in 
their right mind would argue that it is ok to treat animals poorly or that 
they should not have rights. But on the same token I don't believe that 
anyone in their right mind could be so sententious to accuse others of 
differing beliefs to be immoral or unethical. If I keep chickens well and 
treat them with respect, how could one possibly call into question my 
virtues for eating their eggs (which are not alive by any objective or 
subjective definition)?

Perhaps I don't understand properly your beliefs because you have not been 
perspicuous enough, but from what I've heard it sounds like you believe any 
consumption of animal products to be immoral, which following basic logic 
means that anyone who consumes animal products is immoral. That is just so 
ridiculously fallacious that you should win your own award.

Addendum: I also don't believe you fully understand the ramifications of 
farming: all over the US wild boar populations desolate farms and require 
their mass execution in order for you to eat your vegetables. Is it then 
immoral to eat those executed boar? Of course not, and so that is just 
another point that refutes your argument that the simple consumption of 
flesh is immoral.﻿

This is tough...

#1 because he does try hard to be intellectual with his comment but fails

Why can't I reply to Graham Frost's last comment (essay)?  There is so much 
wrong with it.  From a claim that he can disprove a vegan diet in one 
sentence to a 118-line comment - that's one long sentence!  I love how he 
makes it seem like only vegans eat mass-farmed fruit and veg.  And how can 
an industry that, by its very nature, requires the killing of animals be 
less destructive than growing fruits and vegetables?  Plus, rain forests 
are destroyed for the benefit of many industries, which are in no way 
vegan-related.

Most of his arguments do not contest a vegan diet, they merely highlight 
some of the benefits of eating meat.  Sure, meat is a good source of B12 
and other vital nutrients, but this does not mean that these can only be 
obtained from meat.  From my research, the only risk I can find worth be 
concerned with is B12 deficiency.  However, the human body needs so little, 
and stores it for so long, that ensuring an adequate intake is easy with 
either supplements or B12-fortified foods.  A simple blood test from time 
to time will also help keep track of B12 levels.  Also, for the record, 
animals get their B12 from the soil when they eat grass or other plants.

I would just like to point out that any claim that a vegan diet is 
detrimental to one's health is unjustified.  Anyone who does not obtain 
enough vital nutrients through their diet, or consumes too much unhealthy 
food (highly sugary and fatty ones, for example) runs the risk of health 
problems.  This goes for any type of diet, meat or no meat.

I think it's fair to assume that most vegans choose such a diet mainly 
because they don't agree with the physical and mental suffering of other 
life forms.  I don't understand why this should concern anyone in any way.  
Sure, some vegans adopt the 'holier than thou' attitude, but so do certain 
people with any belief; this does not justify an argument against their 
belief, it merely highlights the person's ignorance towards other opinions.

Anyway, I just wanted to get that off my chest.  Thanks for reading.﻿

While it is possible that plants do have a level of ability to feel stress 
and suffering, we do not have good scientific evidence that they do. 
Animals, however, have a central nervous system, and so we do know that 
they can objectively feel pain.

Even if plants could suffer and were of equal consciousness as animals are, 
it would be wiser to continue eating plants. Why? Every 10 calories of meat 
requires the sacrifice of 100 calories worth of plants. This is due to the 
trophic pyramid, which explains how energy is distributed throughout an

Furthermore, predators such as lions are obligate carnivores--meaning they 
must eat meat for optimal health. They have evolved to require animal flesh

them alive. Human beings will not do this, so it is hardly accurate to call 
such activities an 'instinct'. Humans are not obligate carnivores, so any 
meat consumption is done purely by choice. See the ADA's position on meat 
in the human diet:

"It is the position of the American Dietetic Association and Dietitians of 
Canada that *appropriately planned vegetarian diets are healthful, 
nutritionally adequate, and provide health benefits* in the prevention and 
treatment of certain diseases. *Well-planned vegan and other types of 
vegetarian diets are appropriate for all stages of the life-cycle*

Yeah, #1 is a total false dichotomy, a common one too, in the simple fact 
that animals *do* have a vast variance in neurology and thus consciousness. 
Of course animals of mammalia are the easiest to argue for rights, but that 
rapidly falls off as you get further away into fish and more primitive 
animals, and eventually into utter stupidity concerning invertebrates like 
bees.

Would anyone disagree with Descartes that a jellyfish is a machine? It *is* 
an animal, but possesses *no* brain and thus absolutely *no* consciousness. 
Does it get rights just for being an animal? No? Then you need to narrow 
"animal rights". It should instead be "consciousness rights", and naturally 
exclude animals with no consciousness. But that appeals less to emotion,

+Vegan M Some aspects of consciousness are nuanced, especially the closer 
you get towards humans. I'm non-veg but no doubt mammals are all comparably 
conscious.

The further away you get into primitive vertebrates and especially 
invertebrates, though, the quicker it falls off. We know through neurology 
that consciousness requires significant perception, self awareness, and 
memory. And even if not apparent through behavior, if we know a species' 
brain is not reasonably capable of this (or if it has no brain at all), we 
can conclude that it is not conscious or at least not comparable to humans. 

Meaning I'd say Descartes and Einstein are both wrong via 
overgeneralization. But it is very interesting debate on what consciousness 
even is. You might be interested in the Turing Test, which asserts that if 
a computer output behaves like a human, it *is* conscious as well. Highly 
debatable and interesting for the same reasons as animal rights.

Nutrients are often much more bioavailable from animal foods than they are 
from plant foods, a fact that Fuhrman’s ranking system does not take into 
account. The absorption of zinc, for example, is inhibited by phytate and a 
number of other plant chemicals, while it is stimulated by animal proteins. 
Absorption of zinc can be five times higher from animal foods than from 
high-phytate plant foods.9 Calcium is very bioavailable from some plant 
foods such as kale, broccoli and bok choy,10 but very little is absorbed 
from foods high in oxalate such as spinach.11 The absorption of fat-soluble 
vitamins and their precursors such as vitamin K and carotenes can be less 
than five percent in the absence of fat and still less than twenty percent 
with added fat.12,13 Pigments such as lutein are twice as available from 
egg yolks as they are from green vegetables such as spinach.14 As much as 
80 percent of vitamin B6 in plant foods may be bound up with other 
substances that make it unavailable for absorption and use;15 even the 
portion that is available must be converted into its active form in the 
liver in a reaction that taxes the supply of vitamin B2.2 Fuhrman’s 
nutrient density chart would look very different if he adjusted a food’s 
score according to the bioavailability of the nutrients within it.

+MissPandoraC There are certainly some grey areas on the topic you've 
brought up. It's a controversial issue between animal rights activists. To 
me, I try to look at my relationship with other animals in the same way 
that I do with human animals. Would I ever buy a human slave at a store so 
that I could have a friend? Probably not. Would I ever stop my car to pick 
up a homeless human who was crying and starving, bring him to my house, 
pick the ticks off of him, give him a free meal, then gradually keep that 
up if he seemed to really enjoy living with me? Sure. 

Sanctuaries operate as a better-than-the-worst option. Ideally, none of 
those animals would need a sanctuary, but unfortunately many do. Broiler 
chickens have been bred so strangely that they can hardly survive 2 days 
without being waited on by humans. But other animals can still do quite 
well on their own, and some animals have learned that a great way to 
survive in this world is to become friends with a human. While it may not 
always be the best thing for us to look for nonhumans to bring into our 
home, it may be much worse to turn our backs on nonhumans that genuinely 
need and want help from another being, regardless of species.

Gauging all of this is tricky since many scenarios look the same from a 
distance. It's hard for me to tell if my neighbor's dog's all-night-barking 
is him expressing his desperate depression or if it's his love of chasing 
away every squirrel within a 93-mile radius.

I almost agree with most of what vegans say. Almost because, as an example: 
(as in 18:24)
1.humans do not need to eat other animals to live healthy lives.
Correct me if I'm wrong but it would be more accurate to say: 

[Today] humans [in a fairly developed community (or society)] do not need 
to eat other animals [, specially if they take B12 supplements,] to live 
healthy lives.

I know that in this video and others you address some of the points I'm 
regarding here. But the thing I find interesting with summaries is that 
usually they can be understood in a wrong way if they do not address some 
necessary requirements. Some times I think it is better for a summary or 
point to be a little more convoluted, but more precise, than to be simple 
and inaccurate. It is a dilemma, because we can't explain everything and 
every word to communicate, but still with a little more like the above 
example I think it will save you time with misunderstandings and 
misrepresentation of your point of view.

The other reason I almost agree with the points above is also related to 
this intentional inaccuracy when simplifying ideas. By simplifying this 
sentence it doesn't become apparent that the more you think about the 
subject the more explanations you need to put in the sentence to become an 
accurate description of reality, and why this is a problem? The more 
conditions are needed to link HUMAN DIET and HEALTHY lives, the more it 
becomes clear that this is not an easy business as many people make it to 
be by simplifying it. It is not that easy to have a healthy diet for one.

Other points I made as explanation in the phrase, and many more could be 
made (some were even explained in this video like point 4 regarding the 
environment), are conditions that usually will favor the easiest or most 
rewarding outcome when considering a short period of time. So, for 
instance, many poor communities have eating disorders because unhealthy 
products are more abundant, cheaper, addictive, and propagated through 
commercials. One of the reasons it is easy to wrongly exploit this for 
profit is because humans are not so much about reason when it comes to 
eating, but more about reward and satisfaction just like the other animals.

compartmentalize humans as being very reasonable when it comes to diet, 
when they are not. With all those conditions as I mentioned, which are not 
so easy to comply, they don't need in theory (in did not find a better term 
to use here), but even then it would be possible for still feeling the 
necessity.

I think we could evolve in a better society by drastically diminishing the 
culture of what (and who) we eat. We could be much more efficient, but we 
still need a much more equal and healthy society in other larger and 
precedent problems to be able to deal with that. For example, many people 
with a good education and social environment can understand the importance 
of developing clean energy (which I think it is a much more pressing 
matter), but look how few really take action in this regard and how much 
our capitalist society has evolved in a way to block any attempts to change 
that reality. Sometimes even that, which is much less integrated in to our 
emotional needs as food, it is difficult to argue with people.﻿

It's not a "scapegoat" (I assume you mean rationalisation, seeing as the 
word scapegoat doesn't apply in this context), it's how I came to the

Insects do not have complex emotions so cannot suffer or experience 
happiness. This is not an assumption or a "random thing" I "heard on the 
internet", it's a biological fact.

I'm not speaking with a layman's understanding here, I'm a qualified 
biologist.

"Having a lack of proof that they feel does not make it a fact"

Lack of proof and proof that something is wrong are not something that you 
should confuse. We know how simple nervous systems work, and we know where 
all the important nerves are in insects and what their functions are. It's 
not just that there's no evidence that these insects can feel pain, it's 
that it's physically impossible for them to detect and process it.

There are some insects which may be able to feel pain, but we know that the 
ones that we've investigated in detail cannot.

+drumer960 "You have agreed that there is a situation were it is possible 
to attain eggs without an ethical objection."

Yes, but it would be impossible to implement on a large scale. If you get 
eggs from your neighbor's happy chickens, that's great. But it cannot be 
turned into a billion-dollar industry and remain ethical. It's the same 
with dairy. The demand for milk is so high that any attempt to make every 
farm ethical would be futile. Cows need to be pregnant to lactate, so 
either they allow them to mate of their own accord and milk production 
would plummet, or they continue to artificially inseminate them year after 
year. And the calves still have to go somewhere, which would have to be the 
slaughterhouse. Male chickens would have to be disposed of also.

It just couldn't be done.

People clearly desire milk and eggs. You have agreed that there is a 
situation were it is possible to attain eggs without an ethical objection. 
Cows have a more complicated birth and lactate cycle that I have very 
little knowledge about so I refrained from suggesting a method for raising 
cows that would acquire milk ethically. I'm sure there is one. I understand 
that it would be far less efficient but there would certainly be a market 
for it if other methods of acquisition were banned. You also brought meat 
into a discussion it was never a part of don't project your common foe onto 
me I'm not him. a new ethical method of milk production might be the only 
way to end factory farming without slaughtering every animal currently a 
part of it. I don't really see another way but i would be genuinely 
interested in a better one because ending the systematic slaughter with a 
final one doesn't seem to be the ideal solution.

"if i wanted to get some eggs from my neighbor's chickens that would be

The "free range" label is highly misleading. The USDA requirements are as 
follows:

"This label indicates that the flock was provided shelter in a building, 
room, or area with unlimited access to food, fresh water, and continuous 
access to the outdoors during their production cycle. The outdoor area may 
or may not be fenced and/or covered with netting-like material."

Chickens are still confined in overcrowded sheds and still have their beaks 
cut off to prevent pecking each other. The male chickens are still disposed 
of via gassing and suffocation.

Dairy cows are still artificially impregnated yearly and still have their 
calves taken from them at birth. They still develop painful udder 
infections (which the farmers often refuse to medicate because they would 
no longer be organic) and brittle bones from calcium depletion and are 
unable to stand upright. They still become lame and they are still sent to 
be slaughtered after they have been exhausted of milk production.

Obviously this reality is much different to the cows and chickens 
frollicking in grassy meadows that you see in commercials. It's nothing but 
consumer manipulation.

Let's play a game...How many bad assumptions can you find in this 
statement:? "Sentient animals should not be considered resources as they 
have an interest in their own life and liberty that should be protected and 
not taken advantage of."  This statement makes my list of stupid Vegan 
Atheist comments.  

First off is the sentient is a overly broad, vague word and is often used 
incorrectly by vegans and non-vegans alike.  It is completely false that 
all sentient animals have an interest in their own lives let alone their 
own liberty, by definition of the word sentience.  

Sentience is defined as the "ability to perceive subjectively".  It is not 
just any sense of feeling, it has to be subjective.   If were any feeling 
then plants would be sentient, no questions asked.  Does there exist a 
plant species that is more sentient than sponges?  Sponges are often not 
considered vegan (grey area).

How much can you perceive subjectively when you are asleep?  How sentient 
are you when you are asleep?  Can sentience and consciousness be 
interchanged as if they are the same thing?  Which animal species are 
consciousness?  When you are unconsciousness is there any changes to your 
rights?

The problem with the word sentience is that is tends to be a very "top 
down" rather than "bottom up" characteristic.  Top down is where we give a 
human characteristic, in this case sentience, and then work our way 
backwards until we find and organism that doesn't have that trait.  If you 
take it from the bottom up you would expect that you should arrive at the 
same conclusions about what life is sentient but instead you end up with 
having to give plants sentience or end up with having to give neurons 
"magical" significance. 

Too make it worse, neurons aren't even what senses damage tissue.  Those 
are nociceptors and while they are often called pain receptors this usage 
is not consistent with the modern definition of pain as a subjective 
experience.  You need a neural cortex and spinal cord for that. ﻿

Okay, I want to make your next Stupid Meat-Eater Comments video, but I 
found myself getting way to long-winded, trying to address every issue. So 
I'll just stick with two.
First, nutritional requirements. I could go on at length, but I'm sure 
you've heard it all. The mere fact that we have to go to such great lengths 
to obtain animal-based nutrients (manufacturing B-12 from bacteria, 
combining many non-native plant based foods for complete proteins, etc.) 
only reinforces the necessity for meat. If we are to accept that humans are 
animals, we must also accept that regardless of intellect and morality, we 
are still part of the food chain. Which leads me to my second point.

Morality of eating meat. There is an obvious conflict here. I will agree 
that animals are sentient and they do experience a wide range of emotions. 
I will agree that doing something "just because you like it," is 
wrong...although equating eating meat with rape is ludicrous. I don't think 
any rape victim has ever been quoted as saying, "You know when you buy a 
steak from the grocery store? Well, it was just like that." I will also 
agree that most livestock are kept in deplorable conditions. Actually, 
there's nothing to agree with...it's just a fact.

But although animals may feel similar emotions to humans, they aren't 
humans. A sheep does not contemplate its own mortality, a cow does not feel 
disappointment, and a rabbit does not wonder about life after death. 
Killing an animal may seem inhumane, but again, we're part of the food 
chain. It's a necessity. Decapitating a chicken may sound cruel, but I've 
seen what a raccoon does to one. 

Humans may eat meat largely because "we just like it." But we like it 
because we need it. We are animals, no different than a big fish who eats a 
little fish, or a wolf who eats a deer. The difference is that we have the 
option of not tearing an animal apart while it's still alive.

And if you want to point fingers about the horrible livestock conditions, 
point at marketing and advertising. At least here in the U.S., we are 
constantly bombarded with ads telling us to eat more, eat bigger, consume, 
consume, consume. I'd hazard a guess that the typical American (my 
hypocritical self included) eats more meat in a day than they need in a 
week. But as long as there is a demand, there will be a large corporation 
capitalizing on it, ethics be damned.

But what if we did switch to a plant-based diet, en masse? Well of course 
the big corporations would shift from livestock to agriculture. The fields 
used for animal feed could then be used to grow food for humans. Livestock 
related pollution would diminish. And once-domesticated animals could 
return to a broader part of the ecosystem. But would the big corporations 
practice responsible, sustainable farming? Would the advertisers still push 
us to eat more and more of the higher-profit crops? How would the 
mega-farms keep up with demands for higher yields? Genetic modification? 
More aggressive pesticides? We're experiencing all this right now, but it 
stands to reason that given a plant-based culture, it would grow out of 
control.

Well, so much for keeping it short. I don't even care if I make the next 
video now. This turned into more of a catharsis for me.﻿

+Dani Muñoz Guardiola
You seem to have difficulty with my point, perhaps I could rephrase it. I 
do not doubt that animals have consciousness and the nervous system in 
animals confirms that. However, there are degrees of consciousness, sort of 
like a light on a dimmer switch. You can have consciousness that is capable 
of momentary emotion, but not sustained emotion. You can have consciousness 
capable of sustained emotion, but not comparative emotion. You can have 
consciousness capable of comparative emotion, but not abstract emotion, 
etc. (And this is simply in the category of emotions.) The more capable the 
mind, the more types of thoughts it can entertain. That heightened level of 
intelligence (which you conceded in your first response to me) and 
reasoning of each human and their cultural sensibilities and complex 
emotions, etc. that make every human life worth saving to a degree superior 
to that of animals.

As for the kill-counter, we can ask the reverse question. How many of those 
animals would have lived if not for the meat industry? Again, I think you 
can have a serious ethical debate about whether it would be better if fewer 
animals lived than more animals lived and died. A second issue is that a 
kill-counter will naturally skew towards the type of animals that we 
domesticate because they live short lives naturally. Cows, pigs, chickens, 
etc. live for around a decade or less, so naturally, their life-cycle will 
end more quickly. That it is being expedited increases the number only 
slightly.

As for the vegan diet, I was never worried that such a diet is impossible; 
I am sure there is a way to make the diet work with new and inventive plant 
combinations and supplements. However, you are of the view that it is a 
moral imperative to abstain from animal meat and, up to this point, I do 
not hold that you have adequately addressed the intelligence issue save to 
note that the choice of intelligence is arbitrary. I would say that it is 
not since intelligence is a direct indicator of the value of a life being 
lived, in most circumstances, and of its value to society.

Amino acids are the building blocks of protein. When you eat protein, it

subsequent protein synthesis.

I am sorry but your assessment of keeping bees for honey (and hens for 
eggs) shows a great lack of knowledge on the subject and seems to be 
literally "vegan fundamentalism".
Hens lay unfertilized eggs even when a rooster is around. It is therefore 
absolutely possible to keep chicken (in species-appropriate conditions of 
course) without exploiting them especially if you don't keep an 
industrialized breed (so that their bodies are not destroyed by the large 
quantities of eggs they have to pump out). It should go without saying that 
industrial farming of hens isn't only an environmental hazard but also 
animal cruelty of the highest degree and should be abolished. I don't see a 
good argument against keeping them in good conditions (only for their eggs).

Insects like honey bees are not able to suffer in any meaningful way (as 
far as we know). It is save to say they don't have any concept of liberty, 
self determination or anything resembling a capability for emotional 
responses. It is therefore completely ridiculous to call the farming of 
bees "exploitation". The ridiculousness of this comment and your own 
ignorance on the topic seems obvious when we consider that honey is 
substituted by a solution of sugar and nutrients for the bees, so that they 
don't feel a meaningful impact on the hives health. Honey bees are also 
much more industrious than their wild counterparts and thereby able to 
distribute pollen much more significantly (but they are also more fragile 
and therefore sometimes require human support). The argument for symbiosis 
between the species is also not as facile as you would like it to be, since 
humans provide their bees with shelter, food and medicine in return for 
their labor (I have already explained why its not like slavery). The link 
you provided is just another example of such fallacious arguments and whole 
unscientific. What can not suffer (and will never be able to) and isn't 
even really scentient is not worthy of moral considerations.

The often repeated argument that honey is "bee vomit" (and eggs are chicken 
menstruation) and should therefore not be eaten is nothing but a red 
herring fallacy called the argument from disgust (coined by the YouTuber 
TMM; something is morally wrong because I find it to be repulsive. often 
used by Christians and Muslims to argue against gay marriage).﻿

I've been vegan for a few years so let me address a few things.
Yogurt: Coconut, almond or soy. You can even make your own. I personally 
don't eat yogurt, but the coconut one I have tried was good. 
Clothing: Keep in mind that there are many vegan who shop at thrift stores 
and would rather buy stuff that was made in those factories than throw it 
away. Some people still have the same clothes they had before they were 
vegan and choose to keep it rather than waste it by throwing it out. There 
is also lack of accessibility since, unfortunately, over 90% of clothes out 
there are from sweatshops. Lastly, there is the fact that some cannot 
afford the cost of non-sweatshop clothing or some may have been given 
things as gifts. As you can see there are many different reasons. For me, I 
have a lot of the same old clothes from years ago because I maintain my 
weight and I also shop for some clothes as thrift shores.
Diet: Simply eat more fruits and vegetables. I'm on a cleanse right now of 
just raw fruits and vegetables and it is amazing. Many people do it as a 
lifestyle. Just make sure you are eating a variety of whole food and not 
packaged foods. Learn to cook and get creative; there are so many recipes 
out there. You don't need any more than 5% protein. Not only is that the 
recommended amount by the World Health Organization (they found only 2.5% 
was needed, but doubled it for good measure), but also it makes sense that 
we don't need more than that because when you are a baby, you are 
developing the fastest and human breast milk has about 5% so we never need 
more than that. No vegan has every had a protein deficiency. Kwashiorkor is 
only found in poor countries where there is not enough food or people who 
are anorexic. I used Cronometer to measure my macros on this raw fruit and 
veg diet and I am actually getting 5% each day just eating mostly fruit. Of 
course, if that isn't good enough (if you want to body build or something) 
there is always beans, tofu, lentils, nuts, peas, brown rice, ect. Watch 
out though because there is actually a huge problem right now with people 
having too much protein; we only need a little bit.
B12: B12 is actually a bacteria found in soil. If it weren't for soil 
depletion from use of pesticides, we would have enough B12 on our organic 
plants that we consume. The B12 that's needed is a very small amount and 
can easily be supplemented. I've heard injections are the best way to do 
that. I use a tablet, but I'm thinking of switching. Unfortunately, because 
of modern agriculture, that's the only option. Also note that many of the 
livestock now is being supplemented because they are not being feed organic 
grass anyway. We also have a storage of B12 in our body and I've heard 
that, unless you become really sick, it should stay at a constant supply.
Benefit to humans: Animals products to not benefit humans. It makes them 
sick. Look at people around you. They are overweight, tired, need caffeine 
just to get anything done, they're grumpy/moody, they can't think straight 
and they are consumed by society's standards. What you put in is what you 
get out. You put in death, torture and abuse and you don't get out anything 
good.
Cheers!

So although I agree about the benefits of not eating meat, I think we need 
to be realistic that the meat industry will continue to grow and people 
will continue to eat meat, and because we live in a money-driven nation, 
the suppliers will continue to expand to satisfy that need. There are 
several issues in my opinion at play. Back in the 50s and 60s, meat was a 
luxury and families would eat it much less frequently. Obviously such is 
not the case any more and we see the affects of this in diagnoses of 
patients. Processed meat and food with additives and excess sugar intake is 
responsible for a lot of health issues. Also, the more educated a person 
is, in my opinion, the more likely they are to consider dropping meat. 
Unfortunately this demographic is still small relative to the larger 
population. Although I think it's beneficial to continue to put the word 
out there, there does need to be a compromise. Yes, slaughtering an animal 
for food is not a good thing. Yes, meat producers treat animals poorly 
before they are killed. However, I personally do support programs like 
those implemented by Whole Foods that grade suppliers on their practices. 
Unfortunately again, Whole Foods is a place that targets the wealthier 
demographic rather than those consumers that actively support the large 
scale meat suppliers. However, it's still something and consumers need to 
make the ultimate decision that if they will eat meat, if they will 
subsequently be willing to pay a high price for that privilege. Hopefully 
one day veganism will reach enough of a critical mass with enough 
restaurants offering that option, that it will make a dent. However, we are 
still far from that date so need to fight the battle from multiple fronts. 
My two cents.﻿

Feeling and Instinctual Reaction are not mutually exclusive events. 
 Emotions does not automatically give something the capability to employ 
conscious thought or the capability to discern reason.   Emotions are 
Chemical precursors designed to give stimuli better context for a given 
stimulation and in turn provide a higher probability of survival in the 
situations where those emotions occur.  

Plants are Sentient.   Sentience is the capability to feel or perceive 
things.   Biology has shown that things as primitive as single cell 
organisms are capable of 'feeling' as well as 'reacting' to external 
stimuli.  what you are confusing sentience with is reasoning because you're 
attributing sentience with the 'will to live' and the capacity to 'think'.

with all that said... Why do we morally care?
The animals which you seek to protect don't care in kind, and because they 
rarely step above instinctual response (wither or not they are capable is a 
different argument) denotes that they lack a degree of morality on their 
part.

timely justice because they too lack a degree of morality with in them?﻿

The actual hypothesis is that the evolution of bigger brains imposed a 
greater caloric demand on hominids which led them to start eating more 
meat. 

In other words, big brains led to more meat eating, not the  other way 
around.

Oh, and the authors were pretty clear that ANY source of concentrated 
calories -- including fruit, tubers, and oil-rich nuts or seeds -- would 
have been sufficient to meet those  caloric demands.

In other words, there was nothing special about meat, other than its 
convenience for some populations.

I'm not sure if you've discussed oysters.

I'm a vegan. But the argument for consuming oysters (as well as mussels) 
seems pretty convincing. As far as we know oysters are not conscious or 
sentient and do not react to their environment. They do not have a brain or 
a central nervous system. (But they do have nerves). It is argued that only 
creatures with a central nervous system can suffer.

Oysters are essentially the plant equivalent of the animal kingdom. They 
basically stick to a rock and stay there. They may not have any of the five 
senses. They have no eyes, no nose, no ears, no tongue, and possibly are 
unable to feel temperature, pleasure, or pain.
Unlike clams who are able to pump water (flap their shells) to escape 
possible harm, oysters do not. They seem to have no desire or make no 
attempt to escape from harm.


The debate on pain is there. 
They say if you pour lemon juice on oysters they may twitch. But the 
twitching could be from being able to sense chemicals. 
Or to create a pearl a grain of sand must be inserted inside the oyster. 
The sand turns into a pearl to prevent irritation. But I can't imagine that 
from being any different than our own body's reactions to foreign bodies.

Regarding the intelligence and memory capacity of fish, I don't think I can 
agree with what the commenter stated. I've had various types of fish for 
pets and they've displayed behavior that shows the ability to remember and 
discern. For example, I had a Betta fish who would hide or chill in his 
cave when people with whom he was unfamiliar would be looking at the tank. 
However, when I walked close, the fish would dart out of his cave and swim 
to the front as if to greet me. He of course was expecting food, but his 
ability to recognize which human was the one who routinely provided that 
food shows that there is more intelligence and memory capacity than others 
want to give fish credit for.﻿

Studies have shown fish to exceed some primates in terms of memory. They 
often tend to avoid bodies of water where they've been attacked by 
predators or caught by angler fishermen.
